awd_titl_txt: Submesoscale dynamics in presence of freshwater forcing
awd_abstract_narration:
Coastal oceans are dynamic regions where multiple factors including freshwater input from rivers, wind, topography, tides, density gradients, as well as horizontal and vertical mixing influence their circulation and the associated transport of material. Submesoscale flows (of order one kilometer), like small-scale currents, eddies and fronts, are directly influenced by these factors and can strengthen or weaken coastal flows. In the presence of freshwater sources two competing effects can be at play: A freshwater source can, on one hand, enhance density gradients and therefore the generation of ocean fronts, which in turn may deepen the mixed layer, and, on the other, it can stratify the surface ocean and shoal the mixed layer. In some cases, the physical forcing of the wind or tide can reinforce or destroy flow at the submesoscale level, making them difficult to study. This project aims to understand the contribution of freshwater fluxes to submesoscale flow, and of their joint impact on transport and mixing using a regional ocean model. As a case study, coastal waters off Vietnam and the Mekong Delta, where the monsoonal winds are a dominant force and there are large freshwater inputs, will be investigated. This study area has key ecological, social and economic importance. Insights gained from a previous study by the researcher in the Gulf of Mexico will be applied to the Mekong Delta region, exploring possible generalization to other tropical and sub-tropical systems. Furthermore, this project will raise awareness of the existence of coastal submesoscale areas where physical processes are likely to have important, but mostly unexplored, biogeochemical impacts. This project will contribute to a better understanding of cross-scale linkages, from the atmosphere to the land to the ocean or from a kilometer to basin-wide scale. A graduate student supported through this project will gain valuable training in using a regional ocean model configured in idealized and realistic configurations, in-situ data and data-analysis tools. At least one undergraduate student will be introduced to research as part of a Research Experience for Undergraduates (REU) fellowship. Through a collaboration with the Center for Education Integrating Science, Mathematics and Computing at Georgia Tech, a lecture module for grades 6-8 curricula will be developed to promote understanding of near coastal ocean transport in relation to floating pollution, where the concepts of convergence, patchiness and vertical mixing, and the use of models to interpret observations can be introduced. 

This project is a process-oriented study to investigate numerically the interplay between freshwater fluxes, atmospheric forcing, topography and tides on one hand, and surface submesoscale dynamics, horizontal and vertical mixing, and mixed layer depth on the other, in coastal areas impacted by large freshwater fluxes. The main objective is to verify the existence of a generic framework to attribute submesoscale dynamics to different physical forcings in coastal areas. Formation, distribution and impact of submesoscale circulations will be investigated using a regional ocean model run at 0.5 km horizontal resolution. The focus will be on the southwestern South China and the Vietnam coastal region, where the circulation is characterized by strong seasonal upwelling forced by the monsoonal winds, and by large freshwater inputs due to both intense precipitation pulses during the monsoonal cycle and to the seasonally varying inflow of the Mekong River. Sensitivity simulations will help elucidate the contribution of each forcing (wind, heat fluxes, freshwater fluxes, bathymetry, tides) to transport and mixing in the mixed-layer. Regions where lateral density gradients are externally supplied through riverine or rainfall inputs are "hotspots" of submesoscale activities. In these areas submesoscale  processes in general and frontogenesis in particular are not fueled exclusively by the available potential energy stored in the mixed layer, but also by lateral density gradients induced by the freshwater fluxes. Therefore the freshwater fluxes contribute to defining the horizontal and vertical mixing properties, and, at least in part, the seasonal cycle of the submesoscale circulations. The interplay between all possible contributing forcings and the submesoscale circulations, however, is not well understood or characterized.  As a result of this project, the contribution of freshwater fluxes to submesoscale circulations and of their joint impact on mixed-layer transport and mixing under varying atmospheric forcing conditions will be better understood. Furthermore, existing parameterizations may be generalized, making them relevant to other coastal regions subjected to large freshwater sources.

por.por_cntn:
This project refines our understanding of ocean submesoscale circulations (ocean circulation features in the form of eddies, fronts and filaments of vorticity with size of about 1 km in the horizontal) in areas characterized by large density gradients. Those gradients may originate not only from stirring and straining by mesoscale structures, but also from seasonally varying freshwater fluxes.

We focused on three regions: the South China Sea (SCS) and the area offshore the Vietnam coast, which is influenced by the Mekong River plume; the northern portion of the Gulf of Mexico, where the Mississippi River System introduces large freshwater anomalies in late spring and early summer; and the Labrador Sea, where ice-sheet melting causes fluxes of fresh waters across over 500 fjords along the Greenland coastline throughout the boreal summer.

The impact of the submesoscale circulations is highly variable: it modifies the larger scale (~100 km, mesoscale) surface currents in the South China Sea (Fig. 1), while has a lesser effect on the mesoscale circulation in Gulf of Mexico, but there strongly modifies the transport across the mixed-layer (Fig. 2). In the Gulf of Mexico, it also shows a dramatic seasonality which diverges from what predicted by parameterizations that account for the restratification potential of submesoscale eddies, and a strong diurnal cycling. Finally, in the Labrador Sea the feedback of the submesoscales on the basin-wise circulation is such that it influences the formation of deep, dense water through convective events in winter. Through a detailed numerical investigation we found that submesoscale processes modulate the transport of warm and salty Irminger water into the central Labrador Sea and in turn the stratification of the Labrador Sea interior, by controlling the characteristics of the coherent vortices formed along West Greenland. Submesoscale circulations, therefore, modify and control the Labrador Sea contribution to the global meridional overturning (Fig. 3). This portion of our research has put into contest the lesser role of the Labrador Sea in the overall control of the state of the Meridional Overturning Circulation argued through the analysis of recent observational data with respect to estimates from climate models that do not resolve submesoscale turbulence. It also confirmed that submesoscale turbulence scales-up to climate relevance.

While working on this fascinating problem, we also extended our investigation to other planets, realizing for the first time that Jupiter?s poles display an incredible array of submesoscale circulations in and around the large cyclones observed for the first time during the Juno mission (Fig. 4). The Weather Channel will portray a brief description of this discovery in a documentary to be aired in July 2023 within the series ?Weather on other Planets?.

Overall, results from this project were summarized in 8 publications in journals such as Nature Physics, Scientific Reports, Frontiers of Marine Sciences, Journal of Geophysical Research ? Oceans, Journal of Geophysical Research ? Planets and Journal of Physical Oceanography. This grant supported a master student, Xiyuan Zeng, in part two graduate students (Guangpeng Liu and Luisa Lopera), an undergraduate student, Alexandra Sitar, who co-authored one of the papers, and many presentations to national and international conferences, to several Universities in the USA, Japan, Colombia and Italy, to the general public in the USA and Italy, at the Atlanta Science Festival in 2018 and 2019 and to local k-12 schools in the Atlanta area (specifically to the Gwinnett School of Mathematics, Science, and Technology, Morningside Elementary, Centennial Academy Charter School, Laurel Ridge Elementary School and Kincaid Elementary).
